article.headline: Longhorns give loyal fans reason to come back
article.linkText: Hoop 'em Horns? Texas turns back SFA
article.story:
AUSTIN, Texas (AP) -- There were some empty seats and a lot of
misfires.

	   But even on a sporadic shooting night, No. 3 Texas (No. 5 ESPN/USA Today) enjoyed its
highest-ranking ever with an 81-55 win Saturday night over Stephen
F. Austin in the Longhorns' home opener.

	   Brandon Mouton scored 18 points and James Thomas added 13 points
and 15 rebounds on a night Texas generally lived up to the ranking
with tough defense, rebounding and streaky shooting that turned on
at the right time.

	   Texas (2-0) hit just 10-of-37 3-pointers but Mouton went 4-of-6
and snapped the Longhorns' first-half slump that had kept the game
close.

	   "We didn't shoot it well from the perimeter," coach Rick
Barnes said. "But we still scored 81 points."

	   That's because the Longhorns outrebounded Stephen F. Austin
52-33, held the Lumberjacks (0-1) to 31 percent shooting and forced
20 turnovers.

	   Percy Green led Stephen F. Austin with 14 points.

	   Freshman Brad Buckman added 12 points and T.J. Ford and Royal
Ivey each scored nine for Texas. Ford also had 10 assists, hitting
the double-digit mark for the 16th time in his career.

	   The Longhorns return all five starters from last season's team
that made it to the round of 16 in the NCAA tournament.

	   Even so, their home opener came in front of an announced crowd
of 9,658 spread throughout the 16,079-seat Frank Erwin Center. The
arena is under renovations to add luxury boxes.

	   "I thought the crowd was great," said Thomas. "It sounded
like it was more than 9,000 in there."

	   The Longhorns hit their first three 3-pointers in taking a 15-4
lead and appeared ready to overwhelm the Lumberjacks from the
start.

	   Texas went cold after that, hitting just two of their next 12
from long range. Stephen F. Austin was just 8-of-25 shooting in the
first half but cut the Texas lead to 23-16 before Brian Boddicker
and Mouton broke the Longhorns' slump with consecutive 3-pointers.

	   Ford, who led the nation in assists last season and worked hard
to improve his shooting, hit a pull-up jumper, dished an assist
under the basket to Thomas and swished a 3-pointer with 1.2 seconds
left to put Texas ahead 42-29 at halftime.

	   Even though they kept missing, Mouton said Texas kept launching
3s because that's what the Lumberjacks' zone defense was giving.

	   "Considering the way they were playing defense, the shots we
were taking were good shots," Mouton said

	   It was exactly what Stephen F. Austin coach Danny Kaspar wanted.
The Lumberjacks just couldn't handle Texas' defense and rebounding.

	   "Our goal was to make them shoot from the outside," Kaspar
said. "They shot 37 of 70 shots (on 3-pointers). That's what we
wanted. We never play zone."

	   The 'Horns got untracked in the second half as Mouton hit his
fourth 3-pointer and threw down a dunk on a perfect alley-oop from
Ford that made it 56-34 with 14:15 left to play.

	   Ford, who stands just 5-foot-10, put down an emphatic two-handed
jam that made it 70-40 and got his 10th assist on Deginald Erskin's
dunk on the next possession.

	   "We played much better in the second half," Ford said. "We
just got more comfortable and relaxed."
